prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CI 609um Line (Band 4)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observe the CI 609 fine structure line for the Cloverleaf in Band 4.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: In order to maximize the signal/noise ratio of the continuum measurements we use the maximum possible bandwidth. The expected line width (500 km/s) is large relative to even the smallest channel size in Frequency Domain Mode, so we average 8 channels together to limit the data rates (and somewhat match the velocity resolution of the other targeted lines). We center the CI line in the first baseband and arrange the remaining three basebands to provide the maximum continuous bandwidth in both the upper and lower side bands.

The 0.3" resolution was chosen to best match our low-J CO maps (Fig. 1) and to resolve structure in the Cloverleaf beyond just the four images. This resolution was also recommended by the TAC for our Cycle 2 proposal. The largest angular scale is also determined from our high resolution images.

Here we seek to map the [CI] 370 micron line. Table 1 lists the expected line flux from the literature (Weiss et al. 2003) as well as our expected peak line intensity per beam assuming a 0.3" ALMA synthesized beam (per the recommendation of the Cycle 2 TAC), line emission uniformly distributed over the Cloverleaf, and 500 km/s line widths. The later is a reasonable average line width based on the current observations (e.g., Weiss et al. 2005, Riechers et al. 2011b). We determine the size of the Cloverleaf by calculating the emission area of our ALMA Cycle 0 120 micron continuum map. For the 0.3 " beams there are ~15 beams covering the source.
We seek a 5-sigma detection, per beam, integrated over the 500 km/s line FWHM.
The quoted SNR for the continuum detection in Table 1 is for a single 1.875 GHz sideband.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(7-6) and CI 370um lines (Band 6)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observe the CO(7-6) and CI 370um fine structure line for the Cloverleaf in Band 6.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: In order to maximize the signal/noise ratio of the continuum measurements we use the maximum possible bandwidth. The expected line width (500 km/s) is large relative to even the smallest channel size in Frequency Domain Mode, so we average 16 channels together to limit the data rates. We center the CI and CO(7-6) lines in the first baseband. We have one spare baseband to cover the HCN(9-8) and HCO+(9-8) transition, potentially providing additional constraints on the high density gas in the Cloverleaf for no additional time. We arrange the remaining two basebands to provide the maximum continuous bandwidth in the upper side band.

The 0.3" resolution was chosen to best match our low-J CO maps (Fig. 1) and to resolve structure in the Cloverleaf beyond just the four images. This resolution was also recommended by the TAC for our Cycle 2 proposal. The largest angular scale is also determined from our high resolution images.

Here we seek to map the [CI] 609 micron line and CO(7-6) line. Table 1 lists the expected line fluxes from the literature as well as our expected peak line intensity per beam assuming a 0.3" ALMA synthesized beam (per the recommendation of the Cycle 2 TAC), line emission uniformly distributed over the Cloverleaf, and 500 km/s line widths. The later is a reasonable average line width based on the current observations (e.g., Weiss et al. 2005, Riechers et al. 2011b). We determine the size of the Cloverleaf by calculating the emission area of our ALMA Cycle 0 120 micron continuum map. For the 0.3" beams there are ~15 beams covering the source.
We seek a 5-sigma detection of the CI line, per beam, integrated over the 500 km/s line FWHM. We effectively observe the CO line for free.
The quoted SNR for the continuum detection in Table 1 is for a single 1.875 GHz sideband.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 12 and 13CO(8-7) (Band 6)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observe the CO(8-7) line and its 13CO isotopologue for the Cloverleaf in Band 6.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: In order to maximize the signal/noise ratio of the continuum measurements we use the maximum possible bandwidth. The expected line width (500 km/s) is large relative to even the smallest channel size in Frequency Domain Mode, so we average 16 channels together to limit the data rates (and somewhat match the velocity resolution of the other targeted lines). We place the 12CO and 13CO lines in the first and third sidebands, respectively, but slightly off center such that they fit within the sideband edges. We arrange the reamining two sidebands to provide the maximum continuous bandwidth in both the upper and lower side bands.

The 0.3" resolution was chosen to best match our low-J CO maps (Fig. 1) and to resolve structure in the Cloverleaf beyond just the four images. This resolution was also recommended by the TAC for our Cycle 2 proposal. The largest angular scale is also determined from our high resolution images.

Here we seek to map the 12CO(8-7) and its isotopologue, 13CO(8-7). Table 1 lists the expected line fluxes from the literature as well as our expected peak line intensity per beam assuming a 0.3" ALMA synthesized beam (per the recommendation of the Cycle 2 TAC), line emission uniformly distributed over the Cloverleaf, and 500 km/s line widths. The later is a reasonable average line width based on the current observations (e.g., Weiss et al. 2005, Riechers et al. 2011b). We determine the size of the Cloverleaf by calculating the emission area of our ALMA Cycle 0 120 micron continuum map. For the 0.3 " beams there are ~15 beams covering the source. We use the 1-sigma upper limit from Bradford et al. (2009) as the estimate for the CO isotopologue line strength.
Our requested integration time is set by the strength of the 13CO line, and the 12CO happens to fall in the upper side band, effectively observing the line for free. We seek a 5-sigma detection of the 13CO line, per beam, integrated over the 500 km/s line FWHM.
The quoted SNR for the continuum detection in Table 1 is for a single 1.875 GHz sideband.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(11-10) (Band 7)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observe the CO(11-10) line for the Cloverleaf in Band 7.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: In order to maximize the signal/noise ratio of the continuum measurements we use the maximum possible bandwidth. The expected line width (500 km/s) is large relative to even the smallest channel size in Frequency Domain Mode, so we average 16 channels together to limit the data rates (and somewhat match the velocity resolution of the other targeted lines). We center the CO line in the first baseband and arrange the remaining three basebands to provide the maximum continuous bandwidth in both the upper and lower side bands.

The 0.3" resolution was chosen to best match our low-J CO maps (Fig. 1) and to resolve structure in the Cloverleaf beyond just the four images. This resolution was also recommended by the TAC for our Cycle 2 proposal. The largest angular scale is also determined from our high resolution images.

Here we seek to map the CO(11-10) line. Table 1 lists the expected line fluxes from the literature as well as our expected peak line intensity per beam assuming a 0.3" ALMA synthesized beam (per the recommendation of the Cycle 2 TAC), line emission uniformly distributed over the Cloverleaf, and 500 km/s line widths. The later is a reasonable average line width based on the current observations (e.g., Weiss et al. 2005, Riechers et al. 2011b). We determine the size of the Cloverleaf by calculating the emission area of our ALMA Cycle 0 120 micron continuum map. For the 0.3 " beams there are ~15 beams covering the source.
For the high-J transitions we assume that the Cloverleaf does in fact have a higher-excitation component, similar to that of NGC 1068 (Hailey-Dunsheath et al. 2012; Spinoglio et al. 2012), and scale the CO(1-0) line flux from Riechers et al. (2011b) according to the relative line ratios in NGC 1068 (see Fig. 3). While for most lines we seek a 5-sigma detection, per beam, integrated over the 500 km/s line FWHM, the required on source time for a 5-sigma detection would be a small fraction of the overhead in this case. Therefore we ask for a 15-sigma detection here, going 3 times deeper than in the other lines for only an additional 14 minutes. If as suggested by Riechers et al. (2011b) there is only a single low-excitation component in the Cloverleaf, we would expect the CO(11-10) intensity to be only ~3 mJy over the entire source (~0.2 mJy per 0.3" beam; Band 7). By integrating over the entire source, we would expect a 1-sigma RMS in our proposed CO(11-10) observations of 0.05 mJy, giving us a 60-sigma detection of even the lowest possible CO(11-10) line flux.
The quoted SNR for the continuum detection in Table 1 is for a single 1.875 GHz sideband.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NII 205um Line and CO(13-12) (Band 8)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observe the CO(13-12) line and NII 205um fine structure line for the Cloverleaf in Band 8.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: In order to maximize the signal/noise ratio of the continuum measurements we use the maximum possible bandwidth. The expected line width (500 km/s) is large relative to even the smallest channel size in Frequency Domain Mode, so we average 16 channels together to limit the data rates. We center the CO and NII lines in the first and third basebands, respectively, and arrange the remaining basebands to provide the maximum continuous bandwidth in both the upper and lower side bands.

The 0.3" resolution was chosen to best match our low-J CO maps (Fig. 1) and to resolve structure in the Cloverleaf beyond just the four images. This resolution was also recommended by the TAC for our Cycle 2 proposal. The largest angular scale is also determined from our high resolution images.

Here we seek to map the CO(13-12)line and the [NII] 205 micron line. Table 1 lists the expected line fluxes from the literature as well as our expected peak line intensity per beam assuming a 0.3" ALMA synthesized beam (per the recommendation of the Cycle 2 TAC), line emission uniformly distributed over the Cloverleaf, and 500 km/s line widths. The later is a reasonable average line width based on the current observations (e.g., Weiss et al. 2005, Riechers et al. 2011b). We determine the size of the Cloverleaf by calculating the emission area of our ALMA Cycle 0 120 micron continuum map. For the 0.3 " beams there are ~15 beams covering the source.
We have existing measurements of the [NII] 122 micron line from single dish observations (Ferkinhoff et al. 2011) and assume a ratio of of ~10 to obtain our estimate of the [NII] 205 micron line based on Oberst et al. (2006). Our requested integration times are set by the strength of the [NII] line, and the CO(13-12) happens to fall in the upper side band, effectively observing the line for free. We note that this Science Goal is classified by virtue of it being in Band 8. However, based on our previous successful detections in Band 9 when observations were carried out with fewer antennas and at higher resolution than originally proposed for, we think non-standard observing would be both successful and justified in this case.
The quoted SNR for the continuum detection in Table 1 is for a single 1.875 GHz sideband.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NII 122um Line (Band 9)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observe the NII 122um fine structure line for the Cloverleaf in Band 9.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: In order to maximize the signal/noise ratio of the continuum measurements we use the maximum possible bandwidth. The expected line width (500 km/s) is large relative to even the smallest channel size in Frequency Domain Mode, so we average 16 channels together to limit the data rates. We center the NII line in the first baseband and arrange the remaining three basebands to provide the maximum continuous bandwidth in the upper side band.

The 0.3" resolution was chosen to best match our low-J CO maps (Fig. 1) and to resolve structure in the Cloverleaf beyond just the four images. This resolution was also recommended by the TAC for our Cycle 2 proposal. The largest angular scale is also determined from our high resolution images.
We note that this Science Goal is classified as "non-standard" due to both the baseline requirements for 0.3" resolution and by virtue of it being in Band 9. However, based on our previous (partially) successful detection when observations were carried out with fewer antennas and at high resolution than originally proposed for, we think non-standard observing would be both successful and justified in this case.

Here we seek to map the [NII] 122 micron line. Table 1 lists the expected line fluxes from the literature as well as our expected peak line intensity per beam assuming a 0.3" ALMA synthesized beam (per the recommendation of the Cycle 2 TAC), line emission uniformly distributed over the Cloverleaf, and 500 km/s line widths. The later is a reasonable average line width based on the current observations (e.g., Weiss et al. 2005, Riechers et al. 2011b). We determine the size of the Cloverleaf by calculating the emission area of our ALMA Cycle 0 120 micron continuum map. For the 0.3 " beams there are ~15 beams covering the source.
We have existing measurements of the [NII] 122 micron line from single dish observations (Ferkinhoff et al. 2011), but unfortunately the large number of long baselines in our initial Cycle 0 observations (Fig. 1) resolved out most of the flux (Ferkinhoff et al. 2015), so we seek additional time to complete those observations here. While for most lines we seek a 5-sigma detection, per beam, across the 500 km/s line FWHM, here we aim to go 2x deeper since a 5-sigma detection would be observationally inefficient considering overheads. This only increases the toal requested time by ~13 minutes.
The quoted SNR for the continuum detection in Table 1 is for a single 1.875 GHz sideband.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose high resolution mapping of several high-J CO lines and atomic fine structure lines in the z = 2.56 gravitationally lensed quasar HH1413+11 (the Cloverleaf). The Cloverleaf is one of a small number of z~2 galaxies with a well-sampled CO ladder, complete from CO(1-0) to CO(9-8). While the existing CO observations are consistent with a single temperature/density model, this result may be coincidental if differential lensing is boosting emission from warmer gas. High-resolution ALMA observations will allow us to (a) determine how strongly differential lensing is affecting excitation analyses, (b) determine if there exists an AGN-powered high-excitation component, and (c) constrain spatial variation in the gas physical conditions (temperature, density, etc.). We ask to observe four CO lines, one CO isotopologue, and four atomic fine structure lines at 0.3" resolution (~0.8 kpc, magnification corrected). Our proposed spatially resolved multi-line observations, when coupled with our existing low-J CO maps, will constrain the ISM conditions in one of the best-known high-z quasar host galaxies, which will help probe the processes affecting black hole and galaxy coevolution.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Center for Radiophysics and Space Research, Cornell University
